column1: Question 1.1: Does your website and documentation provide a clear, high-level overview of your software?
column3: The documentation provides a clear explaination for the features.

column1: Question 1.2: Does your website and documentation clearly describe the type of user who should use your software?
column3: It is mentioned that this project is developers who want to ease their git experience

column1: Question 1.3: Do you publish case studies to show how your software has been used by yourself and others?
column3: It is mentioned in the video demo that the first team has succesfully used wrapper functionality of gits.

column1: Question 2.1: Is the name of your project/software unique?
column3: The name "Git-Simplified" is unique.

column1: Question 2.2: Is your project/software name free from trademark violations?
Question 3.1: Is your software available as a package that can be deployed without building it?
column3: No building is needed to run gits on your local machine.

column1: Question 3.2: Is your software available for free?
column3: Gits is available for free.

column1: Question 3.3: Is your source code publicly available to download, either as a downloadable bundle or via access to a source code repository?
column3: The repository can be cloned to a local machine

column1: Question 3.4: Is your software hosted in an established, third-party repository like GitHub, BitBucket, LaunchPad or SourceForge?
column3: The project is hosted in Github

column1: Question 4.1: Is your documentation clearly available on your website or within your software?
column3: The general documentation is clearly available on the Github repo, and the specific feature documentations are also available clearly.

column1: Question 4.2: Does your documentation include a "quick start" guide, that provides a short overview of how to use your software with some basic examples of use?
column3: The github repo clearly provides installation steps to use the software.

column1: Question 4.3: If you provide more extensive documentation, does this provide clear, step-by-step instructions on how to deploy and use your software?
column3: The repo does provide extensive documentation in the form of a docs folder present inside the repository, with guidelines on every command implemented in gits,

column1: Question 4.4: Do you provide a comprehensive guide to all your software’s commands, functions and options?
column3: The project provides a comprehensive guide to the commands. https://github.com/harshitpatel96/GITS/tree/master/docs

column1: Question 4.5: Do you provide troubleshooting information that describes the symptoms and step-by-step solutions for problems and error messages?
Question 4.6: If your software can be used as a library, package or service by other software, do you provide comprehensive API documentation?
column3: There is an API documentation right there in the Github repo.

column1: Question 4.7: Do you store your documentation under revision control with your source code?
column3: The documentation is stored in the source code. https://github.com/harshitpatel96/GITS/tree/master/docs
